channel.title: P-8 Automated Correction on
channel.description: Recent content in P-8 Automated Correction on

item.title: Access to Student Grades
item.description: Access to Student Grades #feature #assisting Software could provide access to anonymized student grades such that the grader can set an appropriate grading curve.

item.title: Anchoring
item.description: Anchoring #bias The Anchoring Effect is a well-researched cognitive bias (see Wikipedia Page) whereby people’s decision are influenced by a particular reference points (anchor).

item.title: Anonymity
item.description: Anonymity #feature #assisting The identity of examinees is not visible to the person grading the exam. This prevents potentially bad influence of biases (even unconscious ones).

item.title: Ans
item.description: Ans #tool #overview What is Ans? Ans is a dutch company offering software for online assignments and exams. ANS has already been used at the Faculty of Business, Economics and Informatics for several online exams.

item.title: Assigning Grades
item.description: Assigning Grades #feature #assisting Grading curve can be specified in the tool. Tool already has a predefined set of “basic” grading curves.

item.title: Assisted Grading
item.description: Assisted Grading #concept Assisted Grading facilitates the grading process by assisting the grader in their grading process, e.g. by improving the efficiency of the workflow of the grader.

item.title: Automated Essay Scoring
item.description: Automated Essay Scoring #concept TODO: define

item.title: Automated Grading
item.description: Automated Grading #concept Automated grading facilitates the grading process by automating all aspects of grading with software. Automated grading is conducted without human verification of the grading.

item.title: Automated Grading Suggestions
item.description: Automated Grading Suggestions #feature #automated Tool automatically provides suggestion for graders, e.g. suggestions whether some criteria is fulfilled. Suggestions still have to be verified by human grader.

item.title: Automated Grouping
item.description: Automated Grouping #feature #automated Similar answers are automatically grouped such that they can all be graded at once. Potential would be big if it works well.

item.title: Biases
item.description: Biases We hereby list biases or causes of them which could potentially affect the grading process. It is important to note that we do not provide evidence that these biases actually occur in the grading process.

item.title: Cheating Detection
item.description: Cheating Detection #feature #assisting Automatically detect suspicious patterns in submissions of students. Probably only useful if exam is online as cheating is less of a problem in in-class exams.

item.title: Choice Questions
item.description: Choice Questions #feature While open-ended questions are the focus of our project, a software to grade paper-based exams would probably must have to support different type of choice questions (single choice, multiple choice, kprim etc.

item.title: Code Expert
item.description: Code Expert #tool #overview What is Code Expert? “Code Expert is a ready-to-use and platform independent online IDE that allows thousands of students at ETH ZÃ¼rich to work on open programming tasks in exercises and exams.

item.title: Code Similarity Analysis
item.description: Code Similarity Analysis #feature #automated Coding exercises could either be supported with advanced features (e.g., having unit tests run automatically, checking syntax automatically), or we could treat them as normal “essay” questions that can be supported with rubrics, etc.

item.title: Collaboration
item.description: Collaboration #feature #assisting Graders can collaborate on the grading process of (especially) large exams. There are different levels of collaboration: working simultaneously on the same exam but on different exercises (e.

item.title: Consistency
item.description: Consistency #challenge Grading open-ended questions consistently is a big challenge according to the participants of our survey. The goal is that same (similar) answers are awarded the same (a similar) amount of points.

item.title: Context Effects
item.description: Context Effects #bias Context effects (see Wikipedia Page) describe the influence of environmental factors on ones perception of a stimulus.

item.title: Crowdmark
item.description: Crowdmark #tool #overview What is Crowdmark? Crowdmark is a Canadian company founded by a professor of the University of Toronto. Crowdmark offers software to facilitate the examination and grading process.

item.title: DBF Excel Grading
item.description: DBF Excel Grading #tool #overview What is the DBF Excel Grading tool? The Teaching Center of the Department of Banking and Finance (DBF) developed a tool for the automated creation and correction of problem sets and exams solved in Microsoft Excel.

item.title: Digitization
item.description: Digitization #feature #assisting In order to conduct the grading with a tool, the exams must first be digitized. If the exams are paper-based, digitization would probably happen through scanning of the exams.

item.title: Discrimination
item.description: Discrimination #bias The name of the student may have an effect on the numbers of points awarded (e.g. through gender or race bias).

item.title: Exam Review
item.description: Exam Review #feature #assisting In order to provide access to exam to students, exam review functionality could be supported Prerequisites None

item.title: Feature Categories
item.description: Feature Categories #definition We divide potential features of an semiautomated grading tool into two categories: assisting and automated We define the two categories as follows:

item.title: Feature Scope
item.description: Feature Scope #definition Features of a grading software can be differentiated by the possible scope of their use. While some features can be used are not limited to some type of question/exams, others can only be applied to some type of questions/exams.

item.title: Flag Answer
item.description: Flag Answer #feature #assisting A specific answer can be flagged such that it can be reviewed later Prerequisites None In use Ans

item.title: Free Form Annotation
item.description: Free Form Annotation #feature #assisting Free form annotation would allow additional flexibility for the graders. Would be especially useful if graders use tablet.

item.title: Fully Automated Grading
item.description: Fully Automated Grading #feature #automated Fully automated grading of open-ended questions is to the present day not feasible. On one hand, it is by now technically too hard to provide satisfying results.

item.title: Gradescope
item.description: Gradescope #tool #overview What is Gradescope? Gradescope offers EdTech software for exercise/exam management and assisted grading. The software covers the full “grading cycle” from the submission of students to the publishing of the grades.

item.title: Grading Workflow
item.description: Grading Workflow #feature #assisting Support the grading workflow by incorporating best practices within the tool, or by providing documentation on the grading process.

item.title: Graide
item.description: Graide TODO: Create overview Pricing Â£30 per student/year

item.title: Grouping
item.description: Grouping #feature Similar answers can be grouped in order to grade these answers all at once. This could decrease the workload of grading of open questions and improve consistency.

item.title: Halo
item.description: Halo #bias The “Halo Effect” is well-researched cognitive bias (see Wikipedia Page) which can affect people’s judgment in different situations. On a high level, the halo effect describes the tendency of evaluators to be influenced by previous judgments of personality or performance of an entity.

item.title: Handwriting Recognition
item.description: Handwriting Recognition #concept Recognize text from handwritten documents. This is a way harder problem than recognizing printed text as the variability of handwritten text can be way higher.

item.title: Image Similarity
item.description: Image Similarity #concept Image Similarity Analysis tries to determine how “close” different images are to each other. The similarity of different pictures can be determined using deep learning techniques.

item.title: Keyword Extraction
item.description: Keyword Extraction #feature #assisting Keywords could be extracted from exercises to allow for Automated Grading Suggestions (e.g., granting points on a rubric item when a matching keyword is found), or as a precursor to Automated Grouping (comparing Text Similarity Analysis using similarity in keywords).

item.title: Manual Feedback
item.description: Manual Feedback #feature #assisting Graders can provide a custom note on exercises during grading that is either shown to the student during review or only to other graders.

item.title: Manual Grouping
item.description: Manual Grouping #feature #assisting All of the responses to a given exercise are manually grouped (e.g., using Drag & Drop) in a step preceding the actual correction process.

item.title: Mental Depletion
item.description: Mental Depletion #bias Mental depletion may bias the judgment of people. A situation where this bias manifests is the Hungry Judge Effect.

item.title: Optical Character Recognition
item.description: Optical Character Recognition #concept Optical Character Recognition (OCR) is the conversion of images of text to machine-encoded text. Traditional OCR processes one character at a time and focuses on typed text.

item.title: Presentation of Answer
item.description: Presentation of Answer #bias The way student presents an answer may have an effect on the points he is awarded, also in settings were the focus should solely lay on the content.

item.title: Recognition of Student Submission
item.description: Recognition of Student Submission #feature #assisting Automatically recognize who handed in the exam. Prerequisites None In use Crowdmark

item.title: Rubrics
item.description: Rubrics #feature #assisting A rubric is a set of criteria for the grading of an assignment. In order to evaluate a grade, the rubric is applied to each submission.

item.title: Semiautomated Grading
item.description: Semiautomated Grading #concept Semiautomated grading facilitates the grading process by automating and assisting certain aspects of grading. Semiautomated grading involves automated features which may have an impact on the points students are awarded, but also features which are purely assisting the grader, e.

item.title: Shuffling
item.description: Shuffling #feature #assisting The order of exercises in the grading stack is shuffled to ensure that students are in different grading positions across exercises (e.

item.title: Sorting
item.description: Sorting #feature #automated Present the answers in some sorted order. This should allow the examiner to assess the answer more quickly since he sees a similar answer as before.

item.title: Statistics
item.description: Statistics #feature #assisting Analytics for the graded questions, not neccessarily decreased workload but probably nice to have for examiners. Tool could support basic statistics on the results of each exercise.

item.title: Summary of Initial Survey
item.description: Summary of Survey “P8: Correction of open-ended exam questions through automatization” #survey #summary This document summarizes the results of the online-survey on the correction of open-ended exam questions through automatization.

item.title: Tags
item.description: Tags #feature #assisting Tags could be supported in order to filter out answers Prerequisites None In use Crowdmark

item.title: Text Recognition
item.description: Text Recognition #feature #assisting May be required as a prerequisite for other features (e.g. Grouping). Could also be a standalone feature to enable easier reading of the answers.

item.title: Text Similarity
item.description: Text similarity #concept Text similarity analysis tries to determine how “close” different texts are to each other. There are two different kinds of text similarity:

item.title: Text Similarity Analysis
item.description: Text Similarity Analysis Compare texts between different students, e.g. for essays, probably not too useful because we are mainly focused on content, would decrease workload and (possibly) consistency in some cases, technically probably very difficult to implement.

item.title: Tool Overview
item.description: Overview #tool #overview We created an overview for the grading tools: Gradescope CodeExpert Crowdmark Ans DBF Excel Grading Graide We tried to gather evidence for efficiency gains of Gradescope and Crowdmark.

item.title: Topic Modeling
item.description: Topic Modeling #concept Topic Modelling is an unsupervised machine learning technique that is capable to detect word and phrase patterns and automatically clustering word groups that best characterize a set of documents.

item.title: Workload
item.description: Workload #challenge The workload connected with grading open-ended questions is a big challenge, especially in large courses. This incentivizes people to use other question types (such as multiple choice) in their exams.
